content.description: Steep and slightly overhanging.  Fun moves
content.protection: 8 Bolts with optional gear before the fixed pin(1st bolt), bolted anchor
content.location: Start up the ramp and move onto the face.

content.description: Bolted line on the arete.  One of those that's probably easier for taller people.  This shares the anchor with Endless Plight.
content.protection: 5 bolts.  Optional small gear between first and second bolts.
content.location: The left most route encountered from the approach ledge.

content.description: "In keeping with traditional ratings, Fabrizio and I think that Lake of fire may have some 5.7 on the second pitch but can be easily avoided by moving 3 feet left or right so 5.6 may be considered an old school rating, nevertheless it has only seen 3 ascents with 2 parties confirming 5.6 and the other 5.7.  I would hate to sandbag and I would hate to be downgraded.  It needs some outside ascents to confirm the grade 5.6 -5.7."
content.location:
Approach: From campsite 21, head Sw 100 feet until you reach the large fallen tree,  look uphill and you will notice an old tree fort that has fallen, and cairns.  This is the start of the approach,  follow a good trail heading straight up with cairns every 20 feet  or so.  You will soon begin to move East gradually passing a 15 foot slab laying against a buttress.  Move around it and up toward the pine trees.  continue following the trail and cairns East along the buttress and finally traverse along ledges toward the wall.  It will be very apparent where to go once you hit the buttress to the right of the wall where the climbs are located.

Descent:  From the summit ledge look SW for a pine with a yellow sling tied around it, approx 150 feet of 3rd class will get you to the 1st rappel.  one rope rappel straight down to the other large pine,  this is the second rappel.  Blue slings are wrapped around this station, once again a one rope rappel gets you to within 15 feet of the ground where easy downclimbing 4th class puts you where the approach trail comes up and moves East.  Follow the Approach trail down to the campsites.

I would recommend getting a good look at the location of the wall from the large fallen tree by campsite 20 before starting the approach.  This will give you an idea of the general direction to head on.  Approach time 10 min.  Descent time 20 min from summit.

content.description: "Fritz is definately 5.9, but not sustained as scemitar or the line, rather 5 or 6 moves on the second pitch.  This one is fine as it is.  It has not seen a second ascent." - FA notes 2007
content.location:
Approach: From campsite 21, head Sw 100 feet until you reach the large fallen tree,  look uphill and you will notice an old tree fort that has fallen, and cairns.  This is the start of the approach,  follow a good trail heading straight up with cairns every 20 feet  or so.  You will soon begin to move East gradually passing a 15 foot slab laying against a buttress.  Move around it and up toward the pine trees.  continue following the trail and cairns East along the buttress and finally traverse along ledges toward the wall.  It will be very apparent where to go once you hit the buttress to the right of the wall where the climbs are located.

Descent:  From the summit ledge look SW for a pine with a yellow sling tied around it, approx 150 feet of 3rd class will get you to the 1st rappel.  one rope rappel straight down to the other large pine,  this is the second rappel.  Blue slings are wrapped around this station, once again a one rope rappel gets you to within 15 feet of the ground where easy downclimbing 4th class puts you where the approach trail comes up and moves East.  Follow the Approach trail down to the campsites.

I would recommend getting a good look at the location of the wall from the large fallen tree by campsite 20 before starting the approach.  This will give you an idea of the general direction to head on.  Approach time 10 min.  Descent time 20 min from summit.

content.description:
A good line with good climbing on good rock.  If only it was longer.

Start by climbing the flared crack with difficult pro.  Pull the roof via huge holds and gym climbing moves then finish up splitter thin hands.
content.protection: Gear, tiny to 1.5".  The grey/purple metolius offset cam seemed OK for the start.
content.location: Just right of Optischnauzer, close to the arete.

content.description: Amazingly clean crack and face stemming and brutally sustained. Harder and steeper than it looks from the ground. The roof at the top is actually the easy part. You can set a top rope by traversing over from the Optischnauzer but because the route is so steep you will swing out and not be able to get back on the wall unless you also set many directionals.
content.protection: Takes lots of small gear. Bolted anchor.
content.location: To the right of Endless Plight

content.description:
Not exactly the warm-up for the cliff.

There's a few bushes along with a bird nest (no bird in mid-September).
content.location: Right trending ramp just right of Powerbox.
